overview_of_class: This course will examine the shifting social, cultural, racial, class and gendered meanings that Salsa music has produced for the Latinx community in the US as well as for non-latinx. Ranging from urban masculinity and political opposition to the globalized spaces of dance studios, we will explore how the sounds of popular music become sites for the struggles of power over identity.
name: Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation
title: WCAS LATINO 393-0-1 Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the shifting social, cultural, racial, class and gendered meanings that Salsa music has produced for the Latinx community in the US as well as for non-latinx. Ranging from urban masculinity and political opposition to the globalized spaces of dance studios, we will explore how the sounds of popular music become sites for the struggles of power over identity.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Possess a historical overview of the different moments and styles of Salsa music;
2) Examine power struggles over identity through readings of song lyrics, instrumental arrangements, and case studies of Salsa musicians and performances;
3) Articulate their own ideas regarding the meanings of salsa music in their lives;
4) Understand the ways in which any genre of Latinx popular music and sonic traditions shift social meanings and undergo rearticulations.
5) Develop academic concepts that frame a scholarly approach to Salsa music

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1) Cindy Garcia, Salsa Crossings: Dancing latinidad in Los Angeles
2) Christopher Washburne, Sounding Salsa: Performing Latin Music in New York City
3) Cesar Miguel Rondon, The Book of Salsa: A Chronicle of urban Music from the Caribbean to New York City
4) Frances Aparicio, Listening to Salsa: Gender, Latin Popular Music, and Puerto Rican Cultures
